newsitem.title: FRANCE: Gary Oldman, Michael Jackson hit Cannes festival.
newsitem.headline: Gary Oldman, Michael Jackson hit Cannes festival.

text.p: Britain's Gary Oldman packed an explosive punch in his first turn behind the camera, splattering the Cannes festival on Thursday with a heavy dose of violence, profanity and drug addiction in working-class London.

"Nil By Mouth", the first film to run in the May 7-18 competition, won widespread acclaim for its riveting and partly-autobiographical portrait of a family which holds together only thanks to its women.

Oldman, a former Cannes juror who also plays an agent of an evil empire in Luc Besson's science-fiction spectacular "The Fifth Element", unveiled on Wednesday, competes for the Golden Palm prize with the film he has scripted and directed.

"I wanted to do something that represents me, where I lived and grew up," the 39-year-old Oldman, who starred in Stephen Frears' "Prick Up Your Ears" and Francis Ford Coppola's "Bram Stoker's Dracula", said of a story which drifts in and out of characters' lives in an intricate plot.
"The language is brutal. But I didn't see the point of making a piece that represents a culture and people that I have known, and then watering it all down," he said.

With scenes of domestic violence echoing Ken Loach's "Ladybird, Ladybird", Oldman's is a bare-knuckle portrait starring Ray Winstone of a drink and heroin fuelled family which manages to sustain its existence through a series of odd jobs and shady deals.
Oldman's lighting and camera-work make for stifling, dark interiors in pub scenes and turns outside shots into near-gloom.

"This is a harsh world, harshly portrayed. But the jury can expect a tough, powerful piece of drama which hints at a rare directorial talent. You have been warned," enthused industry magazine Moving Pictures.
Score-writer Eric Clapton described the film as "the perfect depiction of what it's like to be an alcoholic".

Fellow singer Michael Jackson will later on Thursday cast the French Riviera competition in the shade when he climbs the red carpeted steps of the Palais des Festivals for a midnight screening of the 38-minute short "Ghosts", starring Jackson and based on his song 2 Bad.
The first script for "Ghosts" was written in 1993 by best-selling author Stephen King but the project was dropped because of controversy over allegations of sexual misconduct by Jackson.

Oscar-winning Stan Winston, who directed "Terminator 2" and designed the dinosaurs of "Jurassic Park", promises a Jackson no one has ever seen before in a film which blends drama and dance while transforming the character into multiple ghostly figures.

Alongside "Nil By Mouth", Thursday's other competition entry, "The Prince of Hamburg" by Italy's Marco Bellochio is a harrowing account of a 19th century prince's stark choice between his life or heroism after he disobeyed orders as a cavalry commander.
